intro: Juncus acutus megalocarpus, commonly known as the giant spike rush, is a tall, perennial grass-like plant native to wetland environments in North America. It is characterized by its dense, cylindrical clusters of flowering spikes that rise on slender, leafless stems. The plant produces small, wind-pollinated flowers that develop into spikelets containing numerous tiny seeds. It thrives in saturated soils and is often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds. Due to its ability to stabilize soil and provide habitat for wetland wildlife, it plays an important ecological role in aquatic ecosystems.
